Article.ArticleTitle: Do Clinical Exercise Tests Permit Exercise Threshold Identification in Patients Referred to Cardiac Rehabilitation?

AbstractText: To evaluate the feasibility of "threshold-based" aerobic exercise prescription in cardiovascular disease, we aimed to quantify the proportion of patients whose clinical cardiopulmonary exercise test (CPET) permit identification of estimated lactate threshold (θ<sub>LT</sub>) and respiratory compensation point (RCP) and to characterize the variability at which these thresholds occur.

Breath-by-breath CPET data of 1102 patients (65 ± 12 years) referred to cardiac rehabilitation were analyzed to identify peak O<sub>2</sub> uptake (V˙O<sub>2peak</sub>; mL·min<sup>-1</sup> and mL·kg<sup>-1</sup>·min<sup>-1</sup>) and θ<sub>LT</sub> and RCP (reported as V˙O<sub>2</sub>, %V˙O<sub>2peak</sub>, and %peak heart rate [%HR<sub>peak</sub>]). Patients were grouped by the presence or absence of thresholds: group 0: neither θ<sub>LT</sub> nor RCP; group 1: θ<sub>LT</sub> only; and group 2: both θ<sub>LT</sub> and RCP.

Mean V˙O<sub>2peak</sub> was 1523 ± 627 mL·min<sup>-1</sup> (range: 315-3789 mL·min<sup>-1</sup>) or 18.0 ± 6.5 mL·kg<sup>-1</sup>·min<sup>-1</sup> (5.2-46.5 mL·kg<sup>-1</sup>·min<sup>-1</sup>) and HR<sub>peak</sub> was 123 ± 24 beats per minute (bpm) (52 bpm-207 bpm). There were 556 patients (50%) in group 0, 196 (18%) in group 1, and 350 (32%) in group 2. In group 1, mean θ<sub>LT</sub> was 1240 ± 410 mL·min<sup>-1</sup> (580-2560 mL·min<sup>-1</sup>), 75% ± 8%V˙O<sub>2peak</sub> (52%-92%V˙O<sub>2peak</sub>), or 84% ± 6%HR<sub>peak</sub> (64%-96%HR<sub>peak</sub>). In group 2, θ<sub>LT</sub> was 1390 ± 360 mL·min<sup>-1</sup> (640-2430 mL·min<sup>-1</sup>), 70% ± 8%V˙O<sub>2peak</sub> (41%-88%V˙O<sub>2peak</sub>), or 78% ± 7%HR<sub>peak</sub> (52%-96%HR<sub>peak</sub>), and RCP was 1680 ± 440 mL·min<sup>-1</sup> (730-3090 mL·min<sup>-1</sup>), 84% ± 7%V˙O<sub>2peak</sub> (54%-99%V˙O<sub>2peak</sub>), or 87% ± 6%HR<sub>peak</sub> (59%-99%HR<sub>peak</sub>). Compared with group 1, θ<sub>LT</sub> in group 2 occurred at a higher V˙O<sub>2</sub> but lower %V˙O<sub>2peak</sub> and %HR<sub>peak</sub> (P < 0.05).
Only 32% of CPETs exhibited both θ<sub>LT</sub> and RCP despite flexibility in protocol options. Commonly used step-based protocols are suboptimal for "threshold-based" exercise prescription.
